statement.text: Venous valves are bicuspid intimal folds that ensure unidirectional blood flow toward the heart, segment the hydrostatic column to reduce pressure, and enable efficient muscle pump function. Valve incompetence causing reflux >0.5 seconds (superficial) or >1 second (deep) is pathologic.
statement.formal: Pathologic_Reflux: Superficial_Veins > 0.5 seconds; Deep_Veins > 1.0 seconds; Perforators > 0.35-0.5 seconds

explanation.intuition: Venous valves work like one-way swing doors - they open easily when blood is pushed toward the heart, but slam shut when blood tries to flow backward. When these doors become damaged or don't close properly, blood repeatedly falls back down the leg with each heartbeat, causing pressure buildup.
explanation.key_insight: Valve closure is passive, driven by pressure gradient reversal. When you stand up, the blood column above the valve falls back, but the cusps catch it and close within milliseconds. Prolonged closure time (>0.5 seconds) indicates the cusps are damaged, dilated, or destroyed - defining pathologic reflux.
explanation.technical_details: Venous valves are bicuspid structures with leaflets composed of endothelium overlying a connective tissue core. They arise from intimal folds at slight venous dilations called valve sinuses. The sinuses create eddy currents during flow that begin valve closure before flow reversal. Valve distribution varies: calf deep veins have the most valves, decreasing proximally. The external iliac and IVC are typically valveless. Valve failure can be primary (degenerative) or secondary (post-thrombotic damage, dilation from volume overload).
common_misconceptions: Misconception: All reflux indicates valve destruction. Reality: Mild reflux can occur from venous dilation stretching the valve annulus without cusp damage.
Misconception: Valves actively close. Reality: Valve closure is passive, driven by pressure gradient reversal creating retrograde flow that catches the cusps.
Misconception: Valve function can be restored. Reality: Once valves are destroyed (especially post-thrombotic), they cannot regenerate; only surgical valve reconstruction can restore function.

structure.function: Passive closure driven by pressure gradient reversal

distribution.lower_extremity: Most numerous in calf, decreasing proximally
distribution.superficial_system: 5-10 valves in GSV, 7-10 valves in SSV
distribution.deep_system: Multiple in calf veins, 1-3 in femoral vein
distribution.perforators: Single valve directing flow superficial to deep
distribution.absent_in: External iliac vein, IVC typically valveless

notable_locations: Terminal valve: SFJ (critical - first line of defense)
Preterminal valve: 2-3 cm below terminal valve

normal_function: Segment hydrostatic column into shorter segments
Reduce transmitted pressure on distal veins
Enable muscle pump to propel blood proximally
Close with increased distal pressure (reflux prevention)

valve_cycle.opening: Flow toward heart during muscle contraction or proximal suction
valve_cycle.closure: Retrograde pressure catches leaflets, sealing lumen

presentation: Varicose veins from superficial valve failure
Leg heaviness and aching worse with standing
diagnosis: Duplex ultrasound with Valsalva or augmentation maneuvers
Measure reflux duration at each valve station
Map reflux from proximal to distal to identify escape points
treatment: Compression therapy to support valve function
Deep venous valve reconstruction (valvuloplasty, valve transplant) for deep disease

definition.@value: The physiological mechanism whereby bicuspid intimal folds in veins ensure unidirectional blood flow toward the heart, segment the hydrostatic column, and enable efficient venous return through passive closure driven by pressure gradient reversal.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy
AVF/SVS Guidelines on Duplex Ultrasound for Venous Disease

learning_objectives: Describe venous valve structure and distribution
Explain the passive mechanism of valve closure
Define pathologic reflux duration on duplex ultrasound
Identify causes of primary and secondary valve failure
clinical_pearls: Reflux >0.5 sec in superficial veins and >1.0 sec in deep veins is pathologic
The terminal valve at SFJ is the first line of defense against reflux
Post-thrombotic valves are permanently destroyed - they cannot regenerate
Valve sinuses create eddy currents that begin closure before flow reversal
Always map reflux from proximal to distal to identify the highest point of escape
